User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:2.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0.1
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; el; rv:1.9.2.17) Gecko/20110414 Thunderbird/3.1.10

When importing from Outlook, Thunderbird does not take steps to ensure all Outlook categories will find their respectful matching labels so that the existing archiving/categorization of e-mails is lost.

In the beginning there were no possibility for an arbitrary number of labels [1]. After this got fixed, what I describe here is the only step that keeps me from migrating from Outlook to Thunderbird.

Even more when now the PST file format has been opened [2] it would be ideal to be able to move back and forth at will.

[1] https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=114656
[2] http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff385210%28v=office.12%29.aspx


Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. While in Outlook, create some categories
2. Tag some e-mail with those categories
3. Import to Thunderbird from Outlook.


Actual Results:  
You'll see that the categories are not being converted to labels and the tagged e-mails are not taged with their corresponding label.

Expected Results:  
Thunderbird should:
1. Enquire whether the user wishes for Category -> Label migration as well.
2. Get a list of Outlook categories.
3. Create the corresponding Thunderbird labels.
4. When Importing categorized e-mail messages, label them respectively.

comments.text:
I cannot check it myself, but the categories in Outlook should be available as dispidCategories property (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc839648.aspx), and the TB message needs a X-Mozilla-Keys: header with a list of simple strings specifying the labels (I don't know how to set a label in an address book item).

I must note that this Outlook property is meant to construct the Keywords: header, not the labels.

The proper place to insert the X-Mozilla-Keys: header is near http://mxr.mozilla.org/comm-central/source/mailnews/import/outlook/src/nsOutlookCompose.cpp#500 (this is where another MozillaMessaging-specific header X-Mozilla-Status is set).
